School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Guizhou University Guiyang Guizhou 550025 China The direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide (DSHP) through the reaction of hydrogen and oxygen under atmospheric pressure offers a highly atom-economic and environmentally friendly approach. However, this process is hindered by low productivity and selectivity of H2O2. Inspired by the adhesive properties of mussels, we successfully developed a bimetallic nanocluster catalyst, PdxNiy/SiO2@PDA, leveraging strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) for enhanced catalytic performance. Among these, the catalyst Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA demonstrated exceptional catalytic activity, achieving H2O2 productivity and selectivity of 7210.60 mmol/gPd·h-1 and 95.30 %, respectively—representing improvements of 319.51 % and 33.50 % over the unmodified Pd/SiO2 catalyst (1718.84 mmol/gPd·h-1 and 61.80 %). The anchoring mechanism of phenolic hydroxyl and amino groups on the polydopamine (PDA) coating was systematically investigated using control groups modified with tea polyphenols (TP) and 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES), rich in phenolic hydroxyl and amino groups, respectively. Characterization revealed that amino groups on the PDA layer served as the primary anchoring sites, and the phenolic hydroxyl and quinone groups play a role in optimizing the electronic structure of Pd in an electron-deficient state. Synchrotron-based X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) analysis and density functional theory (DFT) calculations further revealed that the incorporation of Ni, a metal with a smaller atomic radius and lower electronegativity, reduced the Pd-Pd interatomic distance and shift the d-band center downwards from -1.72 eV to -1.94 eV. This modification inhibited the dissociative adsorption of O2* at Pd sites, thereby significantly enhancing H2O2 productivity and selectivity. Graphical abstract Graphic abstract: A highly efficient catalyst for direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide was developed through the synergistic regulation of dopamine coating with strong adhesion and binary metal Ni. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide Polydopamine PdNi bimetallic DFT calculation O-O bond dissociation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), a highly efficient and environmentally friendly oxidant, is widely used across various fields, including chemical engineering, environmental protection, medical care, and semiconductor manufacturing [1–5]. Owing to its environmental benefits and efficacy, the global demand for hydrogen peroxide continues to grow steadily [6]. Several methods are widely employed to produce hydrogen peroxide, such as the anthraquinone process, electrolysis, and photocatalysis [7–9]. Among these, the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide (DSHP) from hydrogen and oxygen has garnered significant attention due to its exceptional atomic economy and the generation of water as the sole by-product. However, achieving industrial-scale DSHP necessitates the development of catalysts with high selectivity and productivity [10]. Palladium-based catalysts are commonly used in DSHP. Nevertheless, their application is hindered by challenges such as the migration, agglomeration, and detachment of Pd nanoparticles due to their high surface energy, leading to poor stability during preparation and catalysis [11,12]. Furthermore, Pd nanoparticles can catalyze not only the formation of H2O2 but also the undesired breaking of O-O bonds in intermediate oxygen-containing species (O2*, OOH*, and HOOH*), resulting in by-product water and reduced H2O2 selectivity and productivity [13]. To address these issues, researchers have explored catalyst optimization strategies, including carrier modification [14–16], control of active component size and morphology [17], and compositional tuning [18–22]. Previous studies have shown that increasing the diameter of Pd clusters from 0.7 to 7.0 nm significantly raises the activation enthalpy for H2O formation while leaving the activation enthalpy for H2O2 nearly constant, thus inhibiting O-O bond dissociation [23]. Moreover, by incorporating tin into Pd catalyst and applying heat treatment cycles, a protective tin oxide layer can be formed around Pd particles, which can significantly improve the H2O2 selectivity [24]. However, the active components stability of these catalysts mentioned above needs further improvement. Our groups focused on enhancing catalyst stability and activity through microstructural improvements, the Pd@SiO2 catalysts with a core-shell structure (H2O2 productivity was 396.0 mmol/gPd·h-1 and selectivity was 26.0 %) and Pd@HCS catalysts possessing a yolk-shell structure (H2O2 productivity was 2450.0 mmol/gPd·h-1 and selectivity was 92.0 %) were devised [25,26]. The shell layers of the two catalysts are capable of effectively suppressing the agglomeration and detachment of the active components and display remarkable stability in the DSHP. Nevertheless, the existence of the shell layer may give rise to the issue of mass transfer obstruction, thereby leading to a less satisfactory H2O2 productivity. Here, we proposed a straightforward strategy for directly anchoring the active components onto the surface of the support. Inspired by the marine mussel, researchers discovered that the adhesive proteins secreted by mussels can adhere to a wide variety of substrate materials [27]. Studies on mussel adhesive proteins revealed that they contain a large number of molecular structures of 3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine and lysine. As a natural binders, it’s adhesive protein has a similar chemical structure to polydopamine (PDA) [28]. Therefore, harnessing the exceptional adhesive properties of polydopamine to anchor active components offers an approach for modifying existing carriers. The unique of properties has enabled PDA’s application in various fields [29–31]. Ke et al. [32] modified PET fabric with dopamine to form a polydopamine layer on the fiber surface and anchored Ag nanoparticles on the fiber surface through the chelation between PDA and Ag+ ions, it exhibited good durability and high-performance antibacterial properties. Yuli et al. [33] immobilized Pd nanoparticles on PDA spheres, demonstrating high activity and reusability in the Heck reaction. However, the mechanistic roles of amino and phenolic hydroxyl functional groups within PDA during metal nanoparticle anchoring remain inadequately understood. PDA features an abundant variety and large quantity of functional groups, the functional groups on supports play a critical role in determining catalytic performance. Oxygen-containing groups can stabilize H2O2 [34], while amino groups reduce its decomposition and enhance selectivity [35]. Lucas et al. [36] modified the ligand on the carrier surface for the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide. A large number of experiments have shown that ligands containing hydrogen bond groups usually have higher selectivity than those without hydrogen bond groups. Giacomo et al. [37] encapsulated Pd nanoparticles with cetyl-2-hydroxyethyl-dimethylammonium (HHDMA) ligands, increasing H2O2 selectivity from 10 % to 80 % through enhanced activation energy barriers for undesired reactions. DFT theoretical calculations showed that the presence of the ligand increased the activation energies of hydrogenation and decomposition, thereby improving the selectivity. In this work, we developed a highly active PdNi bimetallic nanocluster catalyst for DSHP by leveraging the robust adhesive properties of PDA through a facile impregnation strategy. This method enables precise immobilization of active components while maintaining optimal interfacial contact, overcoming the limitations of conventional core-shell configurations in catalytic applications. To unravel the individual contributions of amino and phenolic hydroxyl groups in PDA coating during nanocluster anchoring, we innovatively designed controlled experiments using 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES, exclusively containing amino groups) and tea polyphenols (TP, solely possessing phenolic hydroxyl groups) [38,39]. Comprehensive characterization techniques and density functional theory (DFT) calculations were employed to elucidate the roles of these functional groups and the co-catalytic effect of Ni in enhancing performance. The findings demonstrate that amino groups in PDA predominantly govern the anchoring process of metal nanocluster. Furthermore, the strategic incorporation of Ni with smaller atomic radius and electronegativity can further optimize the electronic structure of Pd atoms, suppresses the cleavage of O-O bonds in oxygen-containing intermediates, thereby achieving enhanced catalytic performance for the DSHP. 2 Materials and experimental methods 2.1 Materials Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), tris (hydroxymethyl) aminomethane (Tris), dopamine hydrochloride (DA), nickel chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O), 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Tea polyphenols (TP), dibutyltin dilaurate (DBTDL) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. The solvents ethanol (EtOH, AR) and ammonia water (NH3·H2O, AR) were purchased from Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., Ltd. Palladium chloride (PdCl2, 99 %) was purchased from Xian Bide Pharmatech Co., Ltd. Palladium nitrate (Pd(NO3)2·2H2O, AR) was purchased from Sinopharm Group Co., Ltd (Chian). The above chemicals did not require further purification, and ultrapure water was used in all experiments. 2.2 The preparation of different Pd/SiO2 catalysts 2.2.1 Preparation of Pd/SiO2 SiO2 microspheres were prepared by Stöber method, the specific production process was previously reported [26]. 200 mg SiO2 microspheres were ultrasonically dispersed in 50 mL water, then 253 μL H2PdCl4 (0.075 M) was added and stirred at 25 °C for 12 h. The products were washed with water and centrifuged for three times. Finally, the dried products were reduced for 2.5 h at 250 °C under H2 atmosphere, which denoted as Pd/SiO2. 2.2.2 Preparation of Pd/SiO2@PDA-(1:X) and PdxNiy/SiO2@PDA Firstly, 200 mg SiO2 microspheres were ultrasonically dispersed in 50 mL water, Tris was added until the pH of the solution reached 8.5. Then, DA of different weights was dissolved in 50 mL water, two kinds of solution were mixed and stirred at 25 °C for 10 h. The carrier SiO2@PDA was obtained after drying. The production process of Pd/SiO2@PDA-(1:X) (X represents the mass ratio of DA to SiO2) catalysts was the same as those in Section 2.2.1. In this paper, the catalyst Pd/SiO2@PDA-(1:1) was abbreviated as Pd/SiO2@PDA. The preparation process of PdxNiy/SiO2@PDA is similar to the above, and the precursor Ni was added additionally, where x: y denoted the atomic ratio of Pd to Ni. 2.2.3 Preparation of Pd/SiO2-APTES and Pd/SiO2-TP Firstly, 200 mg SiO2 microspheres were ultrasonically dispersed in 40 mL absolute ethanol, 10 mL water and 1.5 mL ammonia water. An excessive amount of APTES solution (2 mL) was added to ensure saturated grafting on the surface of SiO2. After reacting at 30 °C for 4 h, the product was collected by centrifugation. The production process of Pd/SiO2-APTES catalyst was the same as those in Section 2.2.1. 200 mg SiO2 microspheres were ultrasonically dispersed in 50 mL deionized water, 200 mg TP powder was dissolved in 50 mL deionized water. After mixing evenly, the appropriate amount of catalyst DBTDL was added to the mixed solution, then catalyzed the chemical reaction at 80 °C for 10 h. It was washed with ethanol and deionized water and dried to obtain TP-modified SiO2. SiO2-TP was dispersed in 50 mL deionized water, and 253 μL Pd(NO3)2·2H2O (0.075 M) precursor was added and stirred for 12 h. Then prepared the catalyst Pd/SiO2-TP according to the method in Section 2.2.1. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The morphology and size of the samples were determined by a JEM-F200 transmission electron microscope at an operating voltage of 200 kV. Ten-microliter spots of the product were placed on a 200-mesh carbon-coated copper grid (FCF-200-Cu, Electron Microscopy Sciences). The samples were blotted away after incubation for 1 min, washed with water, and then dried in a vacuum oven prior to the imaging. X-ray diffraction (XRD). The crystal structure of the samples was examined by a D8 Advance diffractometer. The scanning speed was set at 5°/min, and the scanning range was from 10° to 90° with CuKα radiation at 30 kV and 30 mA current. Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra. The functional group structure of the samples was detected using a Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer (FTIR, WQF-520) with a scanning wavelength range of 4000–500 cm-1 and a scanning accuracy and number of scans of 4 cm-1 and 64 times, respectively. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The valence band spectra of each element on the surface of the catalyst were measured by an EXCALAB 250 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. Working pressure of the instrument was 1.3 × 10–13 MPa, and C1s = 284.8 eV was used as a reference for binding energy correction. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD). H2-temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) and O2-temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) were performed on an AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer. Before conducting the testing, the sample was placed in a nitrogen environment and subjected to calcination treatment at a temperature of 300 °C for a duration of 1 h. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS). Details of XAFS analyses, Pd K-edge analysis was carried out at the BL11B beamline of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF) in China. Prior to the testing, the sample was pressed into a thin sheet with a diameter of 1 cm and sealed with a Kapton tape film. The XAFS spectra were recorded at room temperature using a four-channel Silicon Drift Detector (SDD) Bruker 5040. The Pd K-edge Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (EXAFS) spectra were recorded in transmission mode. The spectra were processed and analyzed using the software codes Athena and Artemis. Inductively Coupled Plasma-Atomic Emission Spectrometry (ICP-AES). ICP-AES measurements were carried out using an IRIS Intrepid II instrument from Thermo Fisher Scientific. The catalyst samples were digested with a Multiwave PRO microwave digestion system from Anton Paar. The operating results for the ICP-AES experiments are detailed in Table S1. 2.4 The methods for catalyst evaluation The activity of the catalyst for the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen was evaluated in a gas-liquid-solid three phase glass-jacketed reactor at 0 °C and under atmospheric pressure. The total gas flow rate was 16.25 mL/min, with the flow rate of H2 being 2.25 mL/min, O2 being 4.00 mL/min, and N2 being 10.00 mL/min. A mixed solution of 160 mL of methanol (CH3OH) and 1.8 mL concentrated sulfuric acid (H2SO4) was used as the reaction medium, and the mass of the catalyst was 20 mg in the reaction. The concentration of H2O2 was determined by iodometric titration, and the content of H2 and O2 in the tail gas after the reaction was determined by GC-7860 gas chromatography. The calculation methods for H2 conversion, H2O2 selectivity and H2O2 productivity are shown as follows: H 2 conversion ( % ) = mole of H 2 reacted mole of H 2 fed × 100 H 2 O 2 selectivity ( % ) = mole of H 2 O 2 formed mole of H 2 reacted × 100 H 2 O 2 productivity ( mmol / g Pd · h − 1 ) = mole of H 2 O 2 formed mass of Pd fed × time 2.5 DFT computational details All density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out utilizing the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package [40]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) functional in the Perdue-Burke-Ernzerh (PBE) form was employed during these calculations [41]. The wave function of the valence electron was expanded using a plane wave basis set, and the cutoff energy was set at 400 eV. The Brillouin zone was sampled at a set of K-points determined by the Monkhorst and Pack grid, specifically 3 × 3 × 1. The convergence criteria for geometry optimization were that the energy and force should converge to 1.0 × 10–5 eV/atom and 0.01 eV/Å, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The preparation of PdxNiy/SiO2@PDA and PDA anchoring mechanism The preparation process of the PdxNiy/SiO2@PDA catalyst is illustrated schematically in Fig. 1 a. The silica microspheres were synthesized using the Stöber method, followed by the formation of a nanoscale polydopamine (PDA) polymer layer on their surface through the oxidative self-polymerization of dopamine under alkaline conditions [42]. The layer is denoted as SiO2@PDA, leverages the strong adhesion properties of PDA. Palladium chloride acid and nickel chloride hexahydrate were then used as metal precursors, with the active components anchored to the PDA layer via its abundant amino and phenolic hydroxyl groups. The final bimetallic nanocluster catalyst, PdxNiy/SiO2@PDA, was obtained through impregnation and H2 reduction. In Fig. 1b&c, the formation of the PDA coating on the surface of the SiO2 microspheres can be clearly observed. The thickness of this layer is approximately 16.70 nm, and the average size of the catalyst Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA is 170.51 nm. Moreover, the PdNi nanoclusters are uniformly dispersed on the surface of SiO2@PDA with a uniform particle size of approximately 1.67 nm. The results obtained from high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) are consistent with this, as shown in Fig. 1d&e. Elemental mapping from energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) revealed a homogeneous distribution of Pd and Ni throughout the PDA layer, further supported by a strong N signal indicating the presence of the PDA layer (Fig. 1 f). To confirm the presence of Ni, we etched the Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA catalyst with a 5 wt % HF solution to remove SiO2 and increase the relative content of PdNi. After 12 h of reaction at room temperature, black powder samples were collected via centrifugation and washing, followed by XPS and TEM characterization. From the XPS survey spectra in Fig. S1a, distinct Ni 2p peaks are observed, confirming the presence of Ni in the Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA catalyst. Fig. S1b reveals that the particle size of the active component Pd0.7Ni0.3 increases after HF etching, attributed to the depolymerization and dissolution of the PDA layer under acidic conditions, which reduces anchoring sites and leads to Pd0.7Ni0.3 agglomeration. Similarly, uniform dispersion of Pd and Ni elements is evident in the elemental mapping (Fig. S1b), further verifying the existence of Ni. Additionally, lattice spacing analysis of the Pd0.7Ni0.3 nanoclusters indicated a value of approximately 0.223 nm, which is smaller than the 0.230 nm spacing of pure Pd (111) crystal planes (Fig. S2). This reduction can be attributed to the lattice contraction caused by the incorporation of Ni with a small atomic radius. Such a modification will promote the downward shift the d-band center of Pd atoms [43], thereby inhibiting the dissociation of OO bonds and improving the selectivity of H2O2 selectivity [10,19,44]. Anchoring mechanisms and morphological effects. To elucidate the anchoring mechanism of the PDA layer on PdxNiy nanoclusters, we investigated the effects of specific functional groups using APTES (containing only amino groups) and TP (containing only phenolic hydroxyl groups) as anchoring molecules. These functional groups were evaluated for their influence on the microscopic morphology of the catalyst. Fig. 2 a-l shows the anchoring schematic diagrams and TEM characterization results of the catalysts Pd/SiO2, Pd/SiO2-TP, Pd/SiO2-APTES, and Pd/SiO2@PDA, respectively. In the case of Pd/SiO2, the original silica spheres provided a limited number of hydroxyl groups as anchoring sites for Pd nanoparticles (Fig. 2 a). However, due to the weak metal-support interactions, Pd nanoparticles exhibited poor dispersion, resulting in a relatively large average particle size of 9.52 nm (Fig. 2b&c). Similarity, the Pd/SiO2-TP catalyst (Fig. 2 d), modified with TP (containing only hydroxyl groups), exhibited significant agglomeration of Pd nanoparticles, with an average particle size of 8.62 nm (Fig. 2e&f). This highlights the relatively weak interaction between hydroxyl groups on the SiO2-TP surface and Pd nanoparticles. Conversely, for the Pd/SiO2-APTES catalyst (Fig. 2 g), the modification with APTES improved the dispersion of Pd nanoparticles, resulting in an average particle size of 2.11 nm (Fig. 2h&i). While this size was slightly larger than that observed for Pd/SiO2@PDA, it indicates a strong coordination effect between the amino groups in APTES and Pd nanoparticles [35]. Notably, modification of the silica carrier with dopamine led to a significant PDA coating, confirming the formation of a PDA layer with a thickness of approximately 16.70 nm (Fig. 2j&k). This PDA-modified carrier exhibited an excellent anchoring effect, as evidenced by the uniform dispersion of Pd nanoparticles with a much smaller average particle size of 1.76 nm (Fig. 2 l). In summary, the particle size of Pd nanoparticles across the four catalysts followed the trend: Pd/SiO2@PDA < Pd/SiO2-APTES < Pd/SiO2-TP < Pd/SiO2. This indicates a strong interaction between the SiO2@PDA carrier and Pd nanoparticles, and the amino functional groups in the PDA layer play a dominant role in anchoring the metal. Effect of dopamine loading amount on catalyst morphology. Furthermore, the influence of the amount of dopamine on the microscopic morphology of Pd/SiO2@PDA were investigated. With a fixed amount of SiO2, increasing the SiO2-to-dopamine mass ratio from 1:0.5 to 1:3 led to a progressive increase in the PDA layer thickness (Fig. S3). At higher dopamine levels, the PDA coating evolved into a complete spherical structure. This increase in layer thickness effectively inhibited the agglomeration of Pd nanoparticles. Notably, at a SiO2-to-dopamine ratio of 1:3, no agglomeration of Pd nanoparticles was observed, owing to the higher density of functional groups on the SiO2@PDA surface, particularly amino groups, which provided enhanced anchoring for Pd nanoparticles. XRD analysis (Fig. S4) further supported these findings, as no diffraction peaks corresponding to Pd were detected for catalysts modified with PDA, indicating uniform dispersion and the absence of large Pd crystallites. Conversely, unmodified SiO2 carriers showed distinct Pd diffraction peaks, consistent with nanoparticle agglomeration. 3.2 The catalytic performance and stability of PdxNiy/SiO2@PDA Catalytic activity and stability of Pd-based catalysts. The catalytic performance of various Pd-based catalysts for the direct synthesis of H2O2 was evaluated, and the results are presented in Fig. 3 a. Compared to Pd/SiO2 (1718.84 mmol/gPd·h-1, 61.83 %), catalysts modified with APTES (4894.31 mmol/gPd·h-1, 80.53 %) and PDA (5224.63 mmol/gPd·h-1, 86.69 %) exhibited significantly enhanced activity. This improvement can be attributed to the abundant amino functional groups on the modified carriers, which increased the dispersion of Pd nanoparticles, exposing more active sites. This result is conceptually similar to the Pd/SPE polyelectrolyte membranes system that we reported recently, wherein the presence of the amino functional groups facilitated the H2O2 productivity and selectivity by increasing the dispersion and electronic structure reconstruction of Pd [14].The influence of DA concentration on the catalytic performance of Pd/SiO2@PDA was also investigated (Fig. S5). The results showed that H2O2 productivity increased with higher DA concentrations, reaching a maximum when the mass ratio of SiO2 to DA was 1:1. Beyond this ratio, the productivity gradually declined. This may be due to excessive DA addition, which can lead to excessive dispersion and small particle size of Pd nanoparticles. The formation of a large number of undercoordinated Pd atoms on their surfaces will promote the strong adsorption of reaction intermediates, resulting in promoting O-O bond cleavage to generate water [17,23]. In contrast, the activity of Pd/SiO2-TP (2245.43 mmol/gPd·h-1, 75.48 %) increased only slightly, as the weaker interaction between phenolic hydroxyl groups and Pd nanoparticles limited improvements in dispersion and particle size, as evidenced by XRD and TEM analyses. Interestingly, introducing Ni as a second metal further enhanced the catalyst’s performance. For Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA, the H2O2 productivity and selectivity increased by 319.51 % and 33.50 %, respectively, compared to Pd/SiO2, achieving values of 7210.59 mmol/gPd·h-1 and 95.30 %. This may be attributed to the introduction of metal Ni with atomic radius and electronegativity smaller than Pd, which not only increases the amount of extended Pd ensembles, but also regulates the electronic structure of Pd through the compressive strain and electronic effects of bimetallic atoms, effectively promoting the generation of H2O2 [45]. Moreover, previous studies have shown that the addition of metals such as Ru [46], Pt [47], and Ir [48] can regulate the electronic structure and interatomic distance of Pd, suppress the dissociation of O-O, and efficiently synthesize H2O2. Activity evaluations of PdNi bimetallic catalysts with different molar ratios (Fig. S6) indicated that Pd0.7Ni0.3 exhibited optimal catalytic performance. Furthermore, Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA outperformed comparable catalysts reported in the literature (Fig. 3 b and Table S2). To demonstrate the preferred activity of the Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA catalyst, the H2O2 hydrogenation and decomposition tests were also carried out and shown in Fig. 3 c. The results show that the trend of the H2O2 hydrogenation and decomposition rates for these five catalysts is exactly opposite to the results of evaluation results in Fig. 3 a, and the Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA catalyst has the lowest activity for H2O2 hydrogenation and decomposition. This further confirms that the introduction of a strongly adhesive PDA coating and a second metal Ni with a small atomic radius not only significantly enhances the generation activity of H2O2, but also greatly reduces the H2O2 hydrogenation and decomposition due to their unique synergistic effect. The stability of Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA was assessed through cycling experiments (Fig. 3 d). For unmodified Pd/SiO2, the H2O2 productivity declined by 55.92 % after five cycles. In contrast, Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA retained 83.44 % of its initial activity, demonstrating excellent stability. TEM and XRD analyses of the catalysts before and after the reaction (Fig. 4&S7) revealed negligible Pd nanoparticle agglomeration on Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA, with an average particle size increase of only 0.11 nm (Fig. 4 h). This stability is attributed to the robust anchoring of Pd nanoparticles on the PDA-modified carrier. In summary, the Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA catalyst exhibits high H2O2 productivity and selectivity, excellent reusability, and extended service life. These attributes position it as a promising candidate for efficient H2O2 synthesis. 3.3 Chemical structure of the PdxNiy/SiO2@PDA catalysts FTIR and XRD spectra of the catalysts. FT-IR was conducted to confirm the formation of the PDA coating on SiO2 and the successful grafting of APTES and TP onto the SiO2 surface (Fig. 5 a). The characteristic peaks of SiO2 microspheres were observed, including the asymmetric stretching vibration of Si-O-Si at 1103 cm-1, the bending vibration of Si-OH at 956 cm-1, and the symmetric stretching vibration of Si-O at 801 cm-1 [49]. Comparing the spectra of Pd/SiO2 and Pd/SiO2@PDA, the infrared spectrum of the Pd/SiO2@PDA catalyst shows a bending vibration peak of -NH at 1506 cm-1, and the stretching vibration peaks of -OH/-NH at 3446 cm-1 as well as the asymmetric stretching vibration peak of Si-O-Si are weakened, indicating that dopamine was successfully coated on the SiO2 surface [50]. For the infrared spectrum of Pd/SiO2-APTES, the original hydroxyl vibration peak almost completely disappears and a stretching vibration peak of -NH appears at 3512 cm-1, indicating that APTES was successfully grafted onto the SiO2 surface [51]. In the case of Pd/SiO2-TP, the presence of asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration peaks of -CH2 at 2931 cm-1 and 2857 cm-1, respectively, and a stretching vibration peak of -C=O at 1640 cm-1 demonstrated that TP was successfully grafted onto the SiO2 surface [52]. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was used to further characterize the structural properties of the catalysts, as shown in Fig. 5 b All catalysts exhibited a broad diffraction peak at 2θ = 22.9°, corresponding to the (101) plane of amorphous SiO2 microspheres synthesized via the Stöber method [14,53]. The XRD patterns of Pd/SiO2 and Pd/SiO2-TP revealed distinct Pd diffraction peaks, with the (111) crystal plane being the most prominent, indicating that Pd nanoparticles in these catalysts primarily adopted the (111) orientation. In contrast, the XRD patterns of Pd/SiO2@PDA and Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA showed only SiO2 diffraction peaks, with no observable Pd diffraction peaks. This absence was attributed to the high dispersion and small particle size of the active components on the PDA-modified carriers, as confirmed by TEM images (Fig. 1c&2k-l). Interestingly, the XRD pattern of Pd/SiO2-APTES also lacked distinct Pd diffraction peaks, consistent with TEM results (Fig. S8). This observation indicated that Pd nanoparticles were highly dispersed on the SiO2-APTES surface. The presence of -NH2 groups in APTES likely enhanced the interaction between the carrier and Pd, facilitating the anchoring and uniform dispersion of Pd nanoparticles. XPS and DFT of different Pd binding modes onto SiO2 . To further investigate the composition and structure of the five catalysts, detailed XPS analyses were conducted. The full XPS spectra are shown in Fig. 5 c. The N 1 s peak at 399.9 eV was distinctly observed in the spectra of Pd/SiO2-APTES, Pd/SiO2@PDA and Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA, confirming the successful formation of the polydopamine (PDA) coating and the grafting of APTES onto the SiO2 surface. High-resolution XPS spectrum of Pd 3d for the catalysts, presented in Fig. 5 d, reveal the presence of two doublets (Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2) corresponding to the 3d electron states of Pd0 and Pd2+. For the catalyst Pd/SiO2, the peaks around 335.06 eV and 340.32 eV are attributed to Pd0 3d5/2 and Pd0 3d3/2, while the peaks near 336.33 eV and 341.29 eV belong to Pd2⁺ 3d5/2 and Pd2⁺ 3d3/2, respectively [54]. This phenomenon indicates that both Pd0 and Pd2⁺ species coexist in the catalyst Pd/SiO2, and the Pd2+/Pd0 ratio value is 0.93 (Table S3). Compared with Pd/SiO2, the abundant phenolic hydroxyl groups on Pd/SiO2-TP surface easily capture electrons from Pd nanoparticles, causing the Pd0 3d5/2 peak to shift towards higher energy directions. On the contrary, the electron-rich amino functional groups in Pd/SiO2-APTES catalyst will transfer electrons to Pd nanoclusters, resulting in a red shift of the Pd0 3d5/2 peak. It is worth noting that although the Pd/SiO2@PDA catalyst is similar to Pd/SiO2-APTES in terms of the number of objective amino groups, its Pd0 3d5/2 peak still shifts towards higher energy by 0.56 eV, indicating that electrons transfer from Pd nanoclusters to PDA coating, presenting an electron-deficient state, the corresponding Pd2+/Pd0 ratio value also increases to 0.99, consisting with the report by Ye and co-workers [55]. This electron transfer becomes more pronounced with increasing PDA layer thickness, strengthening the interaction between Pd and PDA (Fig. S9a). This may be attributed to the large number of strongly electronegative phenolic hydroxyl groups and quinone functional groups formed during the oxidative self-polymerization of PDA coating [42]. To confirm this speculation, the N 1 s and O 1 s fine spectra of Pd/SiO2@PDA catalysts are analyzed and listed in Fig. S9b-c. It is found that the N 1 s peaks are shifted to higher binding energy as the amount of PDA increases, while the O1s peaks are shifted towards to binding energy, indicating that the phenolic hydroxyl and quinone functional groups in the PDA coating took away electrons from the Pd nanoclusters, resulting in an electron-deficient state. These results further confirm the strong interaction between Pd nanoparticles and the SiO2@PDA carrier. After doping with Ni, which has a smaller atomic radius, the strain effect in the PdNi alloy induces further electron transfer from Pd to Ni. In Fig. S10, the Ni 2p spectra show the peaks at 852.6 eV and 870.6 eV indicate the presence of metallic Ni0, the peaks with binding energies of 857.3 eV and 875.2 eV indicate the presence of the oxidation state of Ni2+, indicating the formation of PdNi nanoclusters [56]. Similarly, EDS line scanning also confirmed the result (Fig. S11). Thereby reducing the electron cloud density around Pd atoms and causing an increase in the binding energy of Pd0 3d5/2, which is consistent with the results of Liu et al. [57] In addition, the Pd2+/Pd0 ratio of Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA catalyst further increases to 1.16. There are research reports that a high proportion of Pd2+/Pd0 is beneficial for DSHP. Wang et al. [58] found that the oxidized PdO (101) surface exhibited higher H2O2 selectivity than the reduced Pd (111) through DFT calculations, attributed to weakened adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediates and inhibition of O-O bond cleavage. Vu et al. [59] also reached a similar conclusion, confirming through experiments that higher Pd2+/Pd0 ratios exhibit higher H2O2 selectivity. Similarly, the Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA bimetallic catalyst exhibited the highest catalytic activity as shown in Fig. 3 a. Detailed XPS analyses confirm the strong interaction between PDA coating and Pd nanoclusters, which can optimize the electronic structure of Pd atoms in an electron-deficient state. This is beneficial for suppressing O-O bond cleavage in oxygen-containing intermediates and enhancing H2O2 selectivity [18,60]. The DFT calculations provided further insights into the binding energies between various modified SiO2 surfaces and Pd nanoclusters. The SiO2 substrate was represented by a three-layer alpha-quartz (001) surface, as reported by Liu and co-workers [61]. In order to reduce computational complexity and fully consider the rationality of the simulation model, SiO2-TP, SiO2-APTES, and SiO2-PDA carriers were represented by stable adsorption of phenolic hydroxyl, head groups (CH3 NH2) of APTES and dopamine molecules on the alpha-quartz (001) surface, respectively, as shown in Fig. S12. Moreover, the anchoring process of the different carriers to the active component is simulated by adsorbing nanoclusters composed of 13 Pd atoms on the above complexed alpha-quartz (001) models. As shown in Fig. 6 , the binding energies of carriers SiO2-APTES and SiO2@PDA with Pd13 nanoclusters were significantly more negative than that of unmodified SiO2 and SiO2-TP. The more negative the binding energy, the stronger metal-support interactions, which is beneficial for the dispersion of active component [62,63], further elucidating the TEM characterization results (Fig. 2). Among all models, the binding energy between PDA and the Pd13 nanocluster is the most negative (−12.31 eV), indicating the strongest interaction between the PDA coating and the Pd nanoclusters. These findings underscore the critical role of PDA in anchoring Pd nanoparticles effectively. Effects of Pd coordination environment on catalytic performance. To investigate the influence of the Pd coordination environment and valence state on the direct synthesis of H2O2, synchrotron radiation characterization was performed on the catalysts Pd/SiO2@PDA and Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA. Fig. 7 a shows the X-ray Absorption Near-Edge Structure (XANES) spectra of two catalysts compared with those of Pd foil and PdO. The absorption edge energies of Pd/SiO2@PDA and Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA lie between those of Pd foil and PdO, indicating that the valence states of Pd atoms in the catalysts are intermediate between Pd0 and Pd2+ [64–66], which is consistent with the XPS characterization results. The Fourier-transform EXAFS (without phase correction) shown in Fig. 7 b reveals both Pd-O (1.54 Å) and Pd-Pd (2.47 Å) bonds in the two catalysts. The intensity of the Pd-Pd bond of Pd/SiO2@PDA and Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA catalysts is notably weaker than that in Pd foil. This can be attributed the high dispersion of Pd and PdNi nanoclusters on SiO2@PDA surfaces due to strong metal-support interactions, which promotes the formation of a high-valence Pd-O ensembles, consisting with XPS characterization results. Moreover, the Pd-O peaks of Pd/SiO2@PDA and Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA catalysts underwent a blue shift, which may be due to the abundant phenolic hydroxyl and quinone groups in the PDA coating changing its coordination environment. Interestingly, the Pd-Pd bond intensity of Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA catalysts is significantly lower than that of Pd/SiO2@PDA, because the doping of Ni facilitates the formation of isolated Pd sites within PdNi nanoclusters, which is beneficial for inhibiting O-O bond cleavage and improving H2O2 selectivity [67]. It is worth noting that compared with Pd/SiO2@PDA, the Pd-Pd peak of Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA also show a blue shift, confirming that the introduction of small atomic radius Ni caused compressive strain in the Pd lattice, which is consistent with the characterization results of HRTEM and XPS. Wavelet transform analysis at the Pd K-edge (Fig. 7 c-f) further demonstrates that the coordination number and bond length of Pd are significantly reduced, indicating that PDA and Ni synergistic regulate the Pd coordination environment (Fig. S13 and Table S4). This regulation increases the Pd2+/Pd0 ratio and shorten the Pd-Pd interatomic distance, which correlates with improved catalytic performance [68]. Adsorption strength of H2 and O2 on the catalysts. To assess the adsorption strength of H2 and O2 on the catalysts, H2-TPD and O2-TPD characterizations were conducted. Prior to measurement, the catalysts were calcined at 300 °C for 1 h to eliminate decomposition effects on desorption behavior. As shown in Fig. 8 a, a low-temperature desorption peak (< 150 °C) corresponds to the physical desorption of H2, while chemical desorption occurs at higher temperatures. The high-temperature desorption peak is attributed to the release of H atoms dissociated from Pd-H surface species. Among the catalysts, Pd/SiO2-APTES exhibited the largest desorption peak, followed by Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA > Pd/SiO2@PDA > Pd/SiO2-TP > Pd/SiO2. This trend aligns with the highest H2 conversion observed for Pd/SiO2-APTES in Fig. S14. Similarly, the O2-TPD results (Fig. 8 b) reveal low-temperature desorption peaks corresponding to physical desorption of O2 and high-temperature peaks related to chemical desorption of O atoms formed by thermal decomposition of PdO. Notably, Pd/SiO2-TP exhibited the lowest O2 desorption, indicating that phenolic hydroxyl groups effectively inhibit O2 dissociation. For Pd/SiO2@PDA and Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA, a new desorption peak emerged at 308 °C, the lowest O2 desorption temperature. This phenomenon is attributed to the presence of phenolic hydroxyl and quinone groups in PDA coating, which increase the Pd2+ proportion, weaken Pd-O interactions, inhibit O-O bond cleavage, and enhance H2O2 productivity and selectivity. 3.4 Catalytic mechanism of the PdxNiy/SiO2@PDA catalysts To gain more theoretical insights into the remarkable activity of Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA catalyst for the direct synthesis of H2O2, four layers Pd (111) and PdNi (111) slab models were constructed for DFT simulation. Among them, the Pd (111) slab model consists of 64 Pd atoms, while the PdNi (111) slab model is based on Pd (111) and randomly replaces Pd atoms with 19 Ni atoms, as shown in Fig. S15. Firstly, the adsorption energy and differential charge density of O2* on Pd (111) and PdNi (111) surfaces were calculated and shown in Fig. 9 a. The adsorption energy of O2* on the PdNi (111) surface is significantly weaker than Pd (111), at −0.71 eV and −0.75 eV, respectively, suggesting the doping of Ni can effectively weaken the adsorption capacity of Pd sites on PdNi (111) surface for O2* and reduce the electron transfer between O2* and PdNi (111) as the shown the differential charge diagram in Fig. 9 a. This is mainly attributed to the compressive strain and electronic effect caused by the introduction of Ni [69]. As shown in Fig. 9 b, the smaller atomic radius of Ni promotes the shortening of the Pd-Pd interatomic distance, from 2.79 Å to 2.69 Å. It is demonstrated that the lattice of PdNi (111) model is compressed compared the pure Pd (111) model, which is consistent with the HRTEM results. In addition, the addition of Ni promotes the electronic reconstruction of Pd atoms in PdNi (111), and the d-band center shifts down to −1.94 eV (Fig. 9 c), weakening the adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediates and inhibiting O-O bond cleavage. Fig. 9d&e show the potential energy surfaces of the main reaction and side reaction for the DSHP system on Pd (111) and PdNi (111) models. The formation energy of OOH* (O2* + H* → OOH*) on the PdNi (111) surface is 0.003 eV, which is significantly lower than that on the Pd (111) surface (0.132 eV). This indicates that Ni doping is conducive to the formation of OOH* intermediate species. It is worth highlighting that the formation energy of OOH* on Pd (111) and PdNi (111) models is higher than that of O* (O2* → O*), suggesting that O2* is more prone to dissociate into O* in the presence of H* and subsequently generate H2O. Therefore, decreasing the dissociation energy of O2* will facilitate the formation of OOH*. The dissociation energy of O2 * on PdNi (111) surface is approximately −1.41 eV, which is higher than that on the Pd (111) surface (−1.58 eV), indicating that Ni plays a crucial role in inhibiting the cleavage of the O-O bond cleavage at Pd sites. This is attributed to the fact that the doping of Ni facilitates the reconstruction of the electronic structure of Pd atoms, causing the d-band center to shift downward [54,70]. Moreover, compared with Pd (111), the PdNi (111) surface exhibits a lower formation energy (−0.14 eV) of HOOH* and a higher free energy of side reactions (OOH* → OH* + O* and HOOH* → 2OH*, which are −1.73 eV and −1.89 eV, respectively). These results imply that the incorporation of Ni is advantageous for optimizing the electronic structure of Pd atoms, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity for H2O2 direct synthesis. 4 Conclusions In this study, we successfully anchored PdNi bimetallic nanoclusters onto PDA-coated SiO2 microspheres, leveraging the exceptional adhesive properties of PDA and its abundant functional groups. PdNi nanoclusters exhibited excellent dispersibility, a narrow particle size distribution, and cycling stability. Through a combination of experimental characterization and theoretical calculations, it was demonstrated that the strong metal-support interaction between Pd clusters and the PDA layer surpasses other configurations. The amine group on the PDA anchored the Pd NPs, and the phenolic hydroxyl group and the quinone group regulated the Pd to an electron-deficient state. Additionally, the theoretical calculation shows that the incorporation of Ni can reduce the Pd-Pd interatomic distance from 2.79 Å to 2.69 Å and shift the d-band center downwards from −1.72 eV to −1.94 eV, which collectively weakening the adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediate species, inhibiting the cleavage of O-O bond and facilitating H2O2 generation. Beyond presenting a highly efficient PdNi bimetallic catalyst for the direct synthesis of H2O2, this work establishes a versatile platform for studying the strong interactions between metal nanoparticles and PDA coatings, offering valuable insights for the design of advanced catalytic systems. coredata.dc:description: The direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide (DSHP) through the reaction of hydrogen and oxygen under atmospheric pressure offers a highly atom-economic and environmentally friendly approach. However, this process is hindered by low productivity and selectivity of H2O2. Inspired by the adhesive properties of mussels, we successfully developed a bimetallic nanocluster catalyst, PdxNiy/SiO2@PDA, leveraging strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) for enhanced catalytic performance. Among these, the catalyst Pd0.7Ni0.3/SiO2@PDA demonstrated exceptional catalytic activity, achieving H2O2 productivity and selectivity of 7210.60 mmol/gPd·h-1 and 95.30 %, respectively—representing improvements of 319.51 % and 33.50 % over the unmodified Pd/SiO2 catalyst (1718.84 mmol/gPd·h-1 and 61.80 %). The anchoring mechanism of phenolic hydroxyl and amino groups on the polydopamine (PDA) coating was systematically investigated using control groups modified with tea polyphenols (TP) and 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES), rich in phenolic hydroxyl and amino groups, respectively. Characterization revealed that amino groups on the PDA layer served as the primary anchoring sites, and the phenolic hydroxyl and quinone groups play a role in optimizing the electronic structure of Pd in an electron-deficient state. Synchrotron-based X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) analysis and density functional theory (DFT) calculations further revealed that the incorporation of Ni, a metal with a smaller atomic radius and lower electronegativity, reduced the Pd-Pd interatomic distance and shift the d-band center downwards from -1.72 eV to -1.94 eV. This modification inhibited the dissociative adsorption of O2* at Pd sites, thereby significantly enhancing H2O2 productivity and selectivity.

coredata.dc:title: Mussel-inspired dopamine-modified silica microspheres for anchoring PdNi bimetallic nanoclusters: Unlocking superior catalysts for efficient H2O2 synthesis
